{"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}]],"cards":[["markdown",{"markdown":"*Examples:* * *Arwena* * *John Smith* * *Mr. Blake* * *Ugly* * *Nameless One* * *L*"}],["markdown",{"markdown":"*Examples:* * *Ever-hooded edgy hacker raised in orphanage* * *Green-skinned, grumpy ogre* * *Small girl wanting to save the world* * *Brave, light-haired paladin* * *Mysterious, stealthy agent* * *Betrayed Lumberjack seeking vengeance*"}],["image",{"src":"/content/images/2020/12/image.png"}],["markdown",{"markdown":"#### Body Innate, beneficial trait of physical manifestation, can't be lost without a great effort. *Examples:* * *Slightly Overweight (+1)* - for when your weight matters, also protects from physical damage * *Tall (+1)* - for reaching high places and better navigation among tall objects * *Slim (+1)* - makes stealth and getting into narrow places easier, also less likely to be hit by projectile * *Muscled Arms (+1)* - helps in swinging arms quickly and moving heavy objects, good for intimidation * *Agile (+1)* - quick running, higher/farther jumps, better movement accuracy and avoidance * *Cat-eared (+1)* - better hearing, increases alertness #### Mind Innate, beneficial trait of personality or mental capabilities, you can't simply get rid of it. *Examples:* * *Aggressive (+1)* - good for intimidation and impulsive/brutal actions * *Persuasive (+1)* - bending people to your will * *Slow-minded (+1)* - complex arguments and sophisticated tricks don't work on you * *Rude (+1)* - it's easy for you to taunt, provoke or intimidate someone * *Strategic (+1)* - helps in long-term planning * *Honest (+1)* - makes you look convincing when telling truth #### Edge Acquired skill, a finite domain of activities your character is good at. May come from occupation. *Examples:* * *Lawyer (+1)* - for recalling law and using it to accuse or defend people * *Gambler (+1)* - pushing a game's odds for your advantage * *Cook (+1)* - creating a tasteful and nutritious food * *Athlete (+1)* - proficiency in sports and physical activities * *Fire Sorcerer (+1)* - creating and using flames to your advantage * *Dancer (+1)* - for impressing others, better avoidance #### Flaw The trait your character is infamous for. Should bring a clear disadvantage. Contrary to three previous types of traits, Flaw can't be used to gain advantage during the game. Instead, you gain Luck Points for mentioning them during your actions. *Examples:* * *Uncharismatic (-1)* - it's hard for you to influence other people * *Bad-luck Brian (-1)* - things go wrong where they're unexpected * *Greedy (-1)* - you have problems in resisting a chance for material benefit * *Jerk (-1)* - noone sympathizes with you * *Adrenaline Addict (-1)* - you suffer without thrill of action and danger * *Bad Liar (-1)* - rarely succeeds on lying and trickery"}],["markdown",{"markdown":"*Examples:* * *Hidden (+1)* * *Poisoned (-1)* * *Flying (+1)* * *Wounded (-1)* * *Burning Fists (+1)* * *Drunk (-1)*"}],["markdown",{"markdown":"*Examples:* * *Sturdy Meat Clever (+1)* - chopping and cutting animal or plant matter * *Thin Rope (+1)* - getting things from one place to another, tying things firmly * *Trusty Dog (+1)* - can fetch, bite, bark, has good smell and hearing * *Noisy Machine Gun (+1)* - deadly gun delivering multiple bullets, a bit loud * *Capacious Bag of Crayons (+1)* - has tens of colorful crayons you can use to draw on surfaces * *Comfortable Car (+1)* - for fast and comfortable transportation of up to 5 people"}],["markdown",{"markdown":"*Example:* *Tennessee Smith is a mild-mannered professor of history, but in his spare time he travels into the wilderness in search of lost artifacts and treasure. Ruggedly handsome, he always seems to keep his cool, no matter how much danger he is in—and he tends to get into a lot of it!*"}],["markdown",{"markdown":"### 1.7. Drives Your character's wish, motivation, ambition, task or quest he or she has to complete. It gives depth to your roleplay, and helps Narrator in composing meaningful Scenes. Also - if your character ever becomes a NPC, the Drives will form an important hint on what will he/she try to do while you're offline. #### What do you want? Describe, what is the ultimate goal of your character. *Example:* *Tennessee Smith is in search of the Idol of Tot, an artifact he has coveted for decades.* #### What is stopping you? Describe, what events or circumstances make it difficult to achieve. *Example:* *His rival, Giles Fishburne is also after the idol and always seems to be one step ahead.* #### What will you do? Describe, what actions your character will take to reach the goal. *Example:* *Tennessee is desperate to succeed this time and will do almost anything to get the idol - though he would never kill for it.* "}],["markdown",{"markdown":"*Example:* *Tennessee Smith and Lumina met at Harvard where Lumina was giving a presentation on the ancient cultures of Jupiter. Both characters were attracted to each other but Lumina is too focused on her mission to have any romantic dalliance.*"}],["markdown",{"markdown":"*Examples:* * *Barricaded Entrance (+1)* * *Windy Weather (-1)* * *Obscured View (-1)* * *Friendly Companion (+1)* * *Soothing Music (+1)* * *Airless Void (-1)*"}],["html",{"html":"
Roll Result
6 Yes, and... You get what you want, and something else.
5 Yes... You get what you want.
4 Yes, but... You get what you want, but at a cost.
3 No, but... You don’t get what you want, but it’s not a total loss.
2 No... You don’t get what you were after.
1 No, and... You don’t get what you want, and things get worse.
"}]],"markups":[["a",["href","https://img.fireden.net/tg/image/1447/35/1447353770099.pdf"]],["em"],["strong"]],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Lightweight, no-brainer roleplaying system based on "],[0,[0],1,"Freeform Universal"],[0,[],0,", which operates on d6 (6-sided die). Since it's the most common die in the world, you can play it in almost any place with access to basic entertainment (on boring party, in the train, or even in prison!). For when there's no dice, there's also a coin flip variant."]]],[1,"h2",[[0,[],0,"1. Character sheet"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"A simple character sheet, which can be used for both characters played by Players, and the Narrator himself."]]],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"1.1. Name"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Pick a catchy name for your character. Does he/she have a surname? A nickname? Maybe forgot his/her name? Or was never named?"]]],[10,0],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"1.2. Concept"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Try to describe core idea for your character in few words. How would others describe your character, not knowing his/her name? How should your character be roleplayed? Here, you can refer to stuff like character's race, appearance, behavior, occupation, background... It adds flavor to the game and makes explaining your character to others way easier."]]],[10,1],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"1.3. Descriptors"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The phrases you can describe your character with. They're divided to four categories, per default you start with one in each type, with +1 modifier in Body, Mind and Edge, and -1 in Flaw. Don't forget to shortly describe, when exactly does your trait apply. During the game, they will provide bonuses to relevant actions. While choosing them, keep your character concept in mind. Descriptors can't be too general, otherwise we would have completely resigned from custom features and replaced them all with universal "Character Power" (which is a boring mechanics). Look at the chart below. If you're going to use your Descriptor in more than two full game domains (colors), it's a sign the trait is too general and should be narrowed down."]]],[10,2],[10,3],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"1.4. Conditions"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"These are more or less temporary statuses (both negative and positive), which your character may acquire during adventure. You don't define them during character creation, but during actual game they will frequently affect your character's performance and will often represent results of character's actions. Once the Scene is over, all Conditions' modifiers weaken by one. They are removed after reaching +0."]]],[10,4],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"1.5. Gear"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Apart from clothes matching your character's background, you can pick two interesting and/or useful items. They don't have to be one-part items (you can treat quiver with arrows or trilogy of books bound with a string as one item). Every item needs a Detail in form of adjective, as well (make one positive, the other negative) - it makes items unique and alters their uses in interesting ways. No matter the adjective, each your Gear piece per default grants +1 die when used in relevant action. Remember to leave a short description of what can you do better with the items."]]],[10,5],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"1.6. Description"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"In other words, biography. Describe backstory of your character. What happened before he/she became an adventurer? You can also add some short descriptions of places, events, people, organizations or objects your character knows about, and which shaped his/her past. This is the only moment when you have such level of control over the lore connected to your character - after your first session changing the backstory will be increasingly more difficult to play out due to inter-character consistency issues and cause-effect relationships."]]],[10,6],[10,7],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"1.8. Relationships"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Beings your character is especially familiar with. Does your character have friends? How about foes? Maybe a pet? It's the high time to describe them all. Treat it as if you were to define character Concepts for each of them - few words of description, type of relationship and circumstances in which this relationship was created. Who knows, perhaps some of them will appear during the story, roleplayed by Narrator. If you want, you can even pick some other Player's character for one of the Relationships."]]],[10,8],[1,"h2",[[0,[],0,"2. Gameplay"]]],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"2.1. Scene Description"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The Narrator describes the scenery, in which the action takes place. He/she may describe things Player Characters experience with their senses (vision, hearing, smell, taste, touch). Narrator may as well describe side characters or pieces of Gear which occupy the place. The Scene itself can also contain Descriptors (just like characters or Gear do) called Details."]]],[10,9],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"2.2. Character's Action"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"In general, the game is about gaining positive Descriptors and losing negative ones, while inducing negative Descriptors and depriving of positive your enemies and threats. Most of the actions are directed towards doing so, even if it's hard to realize it on first glance."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"After Narrator's description is presented, the rest of the Players may describe their characters' interactions with presented Scene, in turns. If the interaction seems to be nontrivial, the outcome will be dependent on character's Descriptors and Scene's Details. Players are advised to include such Descriptors in their roleplay - to help Narrator find out all relevant factors as quickly as possible. Descriptor is relevant only if it's obviously contributing to either success of failure of some roll. Narrator can dismiss Descriptors he or she finds far-fetched. Characters can additionally boost their odds by sacrificing their Gear or declaring a negative Condition on them. After that, Player rolls number of dice defined by Narrator."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[1],1,"Example:"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Narrator:"],[0,[],0," "],[0,[1],1,"You notice a room with a giant, sleeping, furry beast. There's a closed, wooden door behind it."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Player A:"],[0,[1],1," Robert looks around the room whispering to Janice:"],[1,[],0,0],[0,[1],1,""Hey, there's something alive in there. And it's big". "],[1,[],0,1],[0,[1],1,"He's Observant (+1). Does he find anything hidden or suspicious?"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Narrator:"],[0,[],0," (make +1 roll)"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Player A:"],[0,[1],0," Rolls ["],[0,[2],1,"4"],[0,[],1,", 2]"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Narrator: "],[0,[1],1,"Robert notices the floor around the beast seems to be weirdly green. But you're not sure why."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Player B:"],[0,[1],1," Janice takes advantage of being Stealthy (+1) and tries to move around the beast silently, towards the door."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Narrator:"],[0,[],0," "],[0,[1],1,"As you step on the Green floor, you immediately realize it's Mossy and Slippery (-1)! Janice is about to slip up!"],[0,[],0," "],[1,[],0,2],[0,[],0,"(roll +0)"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Player B:"],[0,[1],0," Rolls ["],[0,[2],1,"1"],[0,[],1,"]"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Narrator:"],[0,[],0," "],[0,[1],1,"Janice not only fails to sneak around the beast, waking it up, but she also becomes Prone (-1)! The beast appears to be a Towering (-1), Enraged (-1) bear! It's trying to wound her critically by making a bite to her throat!"],[1,[],0,3],[0,[],0,"(it's a -2 roll for you in total)"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Player B:"],[0,[1],1," Janice rises her Round Shield (+1), trying to protect her vitals! It's what shields are for! She also tries to be Stealthy again (+1), hoping the bear will miss her. "],[1,[],0,4],[0,[1],1,"(-1 in total, I think)"],[1,[],0,5],[0,[1],0,"Rolls ["],[0,[2],1,"5, "],[0,[],1,"6]"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Narrator: "],[0,[],0,"(Bear has already detected you, and being Stealthy doesn't help in avoiding his direct strike. Anyway, now it would be a -2 roll. Roll one d6 more to compensate.)"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Player B:"],[0,[],0," "],[0,[1],0,"Rolls extra ["],[0,[2],1,"5"],[0,[],1,"]"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Narrator:"],[0,[],0," (We take lowest one, so 5)"],[1,[],0,6],[0,[1],1,"Janice defends herself from the bear's bite with her shield!"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Player A:"],[0,[1],1," Seeing his friend in distress, Robert decides to throw his Dusty Mantle (+1) onto bear's head to confuse it."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Narrator:"],[0,[],0," (Bear is Towering (-1) and Enraged (-1), roll -1 in total)"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Player A:"],[0,[1],1," After discovering low chances of success, Robert decides to take the mantle and wrap it tightly around bear's neck! He also spends his FU point to increase odds."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Narrator:"],[0,[],0," (with your FU point (+1) you'll roll +0 in total)"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Player B:"],[0,[],0," "],[0,[1],0,"Rolls ["],[0,[2],1,"6"],[0,[],1,"]"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Narrator: "],[0,[1],1,"Robert strangles the bear for a while, not only making it Confused (-1), but also making it Unconscious (-1). The encounter ends with adventurers panting loudly. You can hear the downed bear's uneasy breath."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Player B:"],[0,[1],1," Janice says to Robert, standing up:"],[1,[],0,7],[0,[1],1,""Let it live. It's mere a wild animal, doesn't deserve to die.""]]],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"2.3. Action's Resolution"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"It's when Narrator decides, how many of such factors apply to a given type of interaction, possibly adding unexpected factors. After summing up the bonuses (positives) and penalties (negatives) from all the relevant factors, Player rolls number of d6 dice equal to 1 + total bonus and takes highest roll for result. In case if there's more penalties than bonuses, Player rolls 1 + total penalty and takes lowest roll for result. If there's as much bonuses as penalties, Player rolls single d6 die. The outcome depends on number, which was scored as a result:"]]],[10,10],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,""Ands" and "Buts" usually lead to gaining/losing a +1/-1 Condition, or creating Scene's Detail. Fortunate events may pull future odds towards Player's advantage (by +1, on default), while unfortunate events pull towards Player's disadvantage (by -1, on default)."]]],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"2.4. How difficult is Difficult?"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Many things in life are relative - for example, how far should you stand be to be Far (-1)? The System operates on some assumptions and constants, which make forming appropriate Details easier."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Effect"],[1,[],0,8],[0,[],0,"When aiming for severe effects, you decrease your odds. Character gets -1 for each modifier of Condition/Gear/Scene Detail they're trying to create, remove or convert during their action."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[1],0,"Example:"],[1,[],0,9],[0,[],1,"Janice tries to convince guard to give his Padded Armor (+2) to her. Guard is Untrustful (-1) as he doubts if he should give his armor to some stranger at all. To convince him to this singular action, Janice rolls -3 in total due to potential gain of (+2) armor and the fact guard is Untrustful (-1)."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Manpower"],[1,[],0,10],[0,[],0,"Character may resign from upcoming action, declaring help another character in his or her goal, forming a group. A group gets +1 die against opposing target/group if exceeds it twice in number (+2 if three times, +3 if four, and so on, up to +6)."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[1],1,"Example:"],[1,[],0,11],[0,[1],1,"Janice is surrounded by four cooperating goblins. Outnumbering her four times, they decrease her chances in combat by three dice. Before she rolls, Robert decides to join her, declaring help as his action. Currently, goblins outnumber the characters twice, so Janice rolls with just one die of disadvantage."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Time"],[1,[],0,12],[0,[],0,"When preparing carefully, you increase your odds. Character gets +1 for every full Scene they spend on a given task in a row (up to +6). You can't use time for your advantage when situation is tense or target of your action can use his time as much as you do."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[1],0,"Example:"],[1,[],0,13],[0,[],1,"Robert knows the mafia boss will be on his lunch break for a while. He decides to investigate his empty office for as long as possible. Using time to his advantage, he gets +1 to investigation roll."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[2],1,"Distance"],[1,[],0,14],[0,[],0,"When acting at longer ranges, you decrease your odds. Character gets -1 for every 6 tiles (a distance character passes without penalties) between him and his target. If the action requires to touch its target, we assume your character additionally attempts to move towards the target. If the target is acting on character instead - and character is trying to avoid the effect - distance becomes advantage (up to +6)."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[1],0,"Example:"],[1,[],0,15],[0,[],1,"Robert notices the group of cultists, whispering to each other. He tries to eavesdrop their conversation. Unfortunately, he's quite far from them (more than 6 tiles), getting -1 to his roll. Before he rolls, he decides to move few steps closer, staying behind cover. He's now close to them, and may roll without previous penalty."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Because distance is an element of velocity, we also use similar approach to calculate modifiers between objects moving slower and faster."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[1],0,"Example:"],[1,[],0,16],[0,[],1,"Janice is being chased on a highway by black van. It's Driving Very Fast (-2) towards her, capable of moving more than 12 tiles during Janice's action. Because she increased her motorbike's velocity in previous turn, she's Driving Extremely Fast (+3), able to move more than 18 tiles during her action. To get away, she rolls +1 in total."]]]]}

entries.title: Arbor
entries.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[],"markups":[],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"A village to on tropical island Raznth inhabited by a community of dragonborn ruled over by the Arbor family. There are rumours of a male dragon nicked the ‘Wise Green’, who serves as a local patron. True dragon's name is Melchior and he wasn't seen since the Great Event. Most of the village is hidden among the trees and in ancient ruins around it. Dragonborn military is commanded here by four generals, called Qīnglóng, Zhūquè, Báihǔ and Xuánwǔ."]]]]}

entries.title: Mirfield
entries.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[],"markups":[],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"A little, troubled town in the middle of the continent. It serves as colony of the human capital Alisont. Multiple types of cultures thrive and clash here. It is inhabited mostly by humans, and visited often by dwarves of Silvermount, who use it as a breakpoint on their trade route south, to Alisont. You can sometimes find here some elven guests from the adjacent Elysian Forest. Town is known from the Crowing Axe meadery, which meads are exported to the furthest parts of continent. There's also a dwarven blacksmith and general store ran by town's Mayor, Gregor Havicken, around year 336."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"A river named Acsena flows across this place."]]]]}

entries.title: Alisont
entries.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[["markdown",{"markdown":"> Here's a transcript of exclusive report by ASHLN (Ashenland News), hosted by Amy Spice (AS) and featuring Prime Minister Steinbaum (PMS) - who was ready to tackle the pressing questions facing Ashenland:

> **AS:** "Hello there, I hope your evenings are going well - we are joined today by the frontrunners of Alisont's election, I am here tonight to interview the candidates and their plans to move the country forward. We're starting today with our interview of the current Prime Minister, Harvey Steinbaum." 

> The feed cuts to a small room, two chairs facing each other with a table in-between, a pitcher of water and glasses placed to the right side, to the left is a thin stack of paper, with assumedly questions written on it; Entering the room is Amy Spice as well as (with an armed guard), the current Prime Minister. They take their seats and he pours himself a glass of water, taking a slow and long drink before smiling and nodding for the interview to begin; Amy herself is evening out the papers as her leg nervously bounces

> **AS:** "Good morning Mr. Steinbaum, thank you for taking some time out of your busy schedule to meet with us today."
> **PMS:** "Thanks for having me on Amy. It's been a while since I've been able to appear on live Television."
> **AS:** "Well, sir this will be recorded actually.." 
> **PMS:** "Is that so, haha; My assistant told me otherwise- anywaysanyways, to the topic at hand." 
> **AS:** Of course, So for our first question- If your initiative for using SEPs (Super Empowered People) would be taken through to fruition, what do you mean by 'Policing' and what would it ultimately mean for the standard citizen?" 
> **PMS:** "Well, I'm glad you asked that- great question by the way, but the answer simply is - as far as I see it - there isn't enough law and order, just the other day I had more protestors to this movement delaying traffic and small businesses..."
> **PMS:** "It simply does not bode well for the future as I predict. Now for what it means- It means a safer, cleaner street for everyone. And those who are dangerous for everyone - they will be dealt with very easily, I recently have reached out and gotten some strings pulled so that I can assemble a task force specifically to deal with these problems rapidly."
> **AS:** "Next, how do you feel your chances are in the upcoming election?" 
> **PMS:** "I feel like my chances are great at the moment, what with the new implementations and park deals I'm making, there'll be a lot of good-faith that I will show to those who have elected me before, they'll get another term of what they ask for.""}]],"markups":[["em"]],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Rather big, emanating with life city inhabited primarily by humans."]]],[1,"h2",[[0,[],0,"Middle Ages"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"In year 336 after Great Event majority of inhabitants were of human kin, but the city is considered the most ethnically diverse in the whole Ashenland. Where are the humans, are usually dwarves and elves. Races here live in peace, cross breeding with each other. As a result - town is full of half-blooded humanoids. The town is supplied by farms placed on the north, beyond the strong, outer wall which protects the citizens."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The city was known, among other things, during the Great Event, town rulers used undead to defend from invaders."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"City consists of four major districts:"]]],[3,"ul",[[[0,[],0,"Trade District - shops and guards barracks"]],[[0,[],0,"District of Wonders - asylum for social outcasts"]],[[0,[],0,"Temple District - temples and entrance to sewers"]],[[0,[],0,"Noble District - authority institutions, court"]]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Theres a river named Acsena flowing across the Noble and Temple districts, being the main medium of trade with foreign nations. Not far from the town, there's a border of Elysian Forest to the west. East of here people can find a large desert spreading up to the horizon."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"People here are of many cultures, but the most known gods here are Almaris (native deity), Kousher (brought in by fire priests), and - due to dwarven contacts - Murn."]]],[1,"h2",[[0,[],0,"Modern Times"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"After industrial transformation, the town's area expanded vastly towards its adjacent colonies (with most notable being Mirfield), transforming them into city's districts. The country-sized town soon became a republic governed by the wealthiest, most influential families of the town. The families, acting as political parties, have been always trying to gain support of citizens' votes - but only the most popular party had a right to elect a representative of the whole city."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The country grew stable, using both supernatural powers and technology to complete its economical goals. A research project of name Scientific Analysis of Energy Origin was formed to gain advantage over Alisont's competition."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"On top of old districts, new ones were founded as the city's expansion went further:"]]],[3,"ul",[[[0,[],0,"City Center - public sector occupied by wealthiest businesses and skyscrapers of ruling families"]],[[0,[],0,"Industrial District - factories, facilities, bars and tenement buildings"]],[[0,[],0,"District of Wonders - slum district with high crime rate"]],[[0,[],0,"Outskirts - quiet habitat consisting of one-family houses and parks"]],[[0,[],0,"Military base - barracks, proving grounds and equipment storage of Alisont's army"]]]],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"Government System"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Alisont is democratically Governed by a council of Politicians which oversee different agencies and beaurocratic centers dedicated to different sectors of the Citys workings. Their decisions are constricted only by the Codus Judia - a constitution supposedly written by the founders of Alisont, dictating the make up of all public institutions. The agencies dictate the flow of resources through the city, and have a large amount of wealth at their disposal thanks to the taxes they collect from the industries they provide with goods."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Politicians are voted upon by the citizens, with the city being split up into several hundred areas, each of which have one representative. Political parties can be created by anyone, and for any cause, but this is already where the diplomatic foundation of Alisonts political situation begins to crumble, as parties receive no funds for campaigning.  A small oversight, but still, in practice this makes it practically impossible for any non established party to be voted into office, except for those of particularly eccentric billionaires."]]],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"Faults in the system"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"From there on, similar trends can be seen in every part of this system.  Politicians may be democratically elected, but gerrymandering runs rampant, making elections not a representation of the citizens will, but instead a battle of wits and chance between rivaling politicians. The agencies, while disconnected from the political council directly, are no better. More specifically, they are bloated. Due to a ruling in the Codus Judia which allows superiors to create permanent positions based on their own judgement, nepotism and similar inequities have lead to more and more jobs being redundant, so much even that if counted as a collective, the agencies would easily employ 15-20% of Alisonts workforce at any time. On top of this, all elections use what are referred to as electors, a little known position, only available to politicians who had been elected for at least 3 terms in full. It is a little known fact that the Codus Judia dictates not that politicians be elected directly by the Citizens, but that the Public votes results be given to these electors so that they can make an informed choice considering the will of the people for the best of Alisont. As would be expected, this is by now little more then a tool for the established partys to freely decide on the results of votes themselves, with the exact results becoming lost deeply within the many files of the Agencys. Talking about established parties, there are two main - a left wing and a right wing one, which hold opposing stances on most any issue, often even taking the opposing stance solely because it "],[0,[0,0],2,"is"],[0,[],0," the opposition."]]],[10,0],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"Rebellion Outbreak"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"In year 1295, a major rebellion outbreak has struck the city's streets. The government was accused of holding an unfair monopoly for superpowers. As equality movements took the lead, people demanded extra taxation for innate superpower users. It's when the proofs of non-humanitarian experiments on humans emerged, causing the highest rebellion spike. The government - in act of response - decided to train superpower soldiers in order to silence the most radical groups of rebels. At the same time - on ashes of destabilizing country - a number of grim cults gained on popularity, recruiting many people who have lost their faith in government's role."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"A video threat was published in the media, which featured freshly beheaded remains of general Jerrod, who at that time was engaged with counter-terroristic actions."]]]]}

entries.title: District of Wonders
entries.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[],"markups":[],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Slum district of Alisont allegedly named after the miraculous deeds of a famous thief, Gathaspa Nubilus. It prides itself on having the most ethnically varied culture from all places in the city - as well as the crime rate."]]],[1,"h2",[[0,[],0,"History of the Slums"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The slums include a wide demographic variety with the presence of many races in it. Many of which had been living there since a time where humans used to ostracize them. Looking back to its origin, the slums were first inhabited by exiled members of animalistic races, which werent accepted inside the city. But, during the industrial revolution, many factories were built in it, exploiting the massive expanses surrounding the city along with the close proximity to the river and the abundance of jobless residents. This led to some of the poorer residents of Alisont to move there so they could be closer to their workplace. With the passage of many years, the presence of factories dumping all their waste into the river made the stench of the slums worse and contributed to the spread of a variety of diseases. Still, other than a rare few, most of the factories in the slum were closed a few decades ago due to the complaints of many citizens of the city which had bought fish from the slums. That of which led to a major governmental investigation which forced their closure along with the forcing of laws against opening new factories there. And so, many of these abandoned factories became bases for the gangs. After a few decades, the river has finally been declared safe enough for people to fish from it, thus improving the social situation of the slums a bit. Nowadays, the slums is still a dreadful place for the people who have no choice but to live there, even if to those who only glance at it from outside, it may not seem to not be as bad as it is."]]],[1,"h2",[[0,[],0,"Modern Slums"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The slums are a particularly dangerous part of the city of Alisont. Although, in the day, most people wouldnt find much of a difference to the interior part of the city and the slums, other than the horrible stench covering it and the dusty older style of buildings. If you were to search its alleys and taverns, it would be quite common to find violent behaviors including brawls that in some cases might lead to deaths. Still, if you can ignore the smell and the dust, the presence of a river enveloping it along with many kind-hearted citizens can make it a bearable place as long as you stay away from these alleys and taverns. Still, a rule almost every resident of the slums knows is to never get out of their homes at night, for that is the period where most gangs are active. Due to them, many children and adults have either gone missing or lost all their belongings."]]]]}

entries.title: Elyse Allanar
entries.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[],"markups":[],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The home city to the elves of Ashenland. Elyse Allanar is called the everlasting grove. After the home tree of the forest was touched by Lady of Forests, the area grew trees that pulse and glow with pure life energy. An elven Druid named Adaris Nevaril spoke to Lady of Forests through the soul tree asking her with great desperation if he and his clan could live in the forest. Lady of Forests heard Adaris and the pleas of his clan allowing them sanctuary, Making magnificent homes for them from trees of iron and crystal. In return they had to make a vow to always protect the forest and and all costs never let anyone from outside his clan near the soul tree for if blood other than his or his kin. Where to touch the trees roots another spell plague would happen this time removing all natural magic from the arcane wilds. Elysian elves together with Dragons and dragonborns from Raznth Island fought near Ketu before Great Event."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Inside the city there's a bunch of shops ran by local elves: general store, clothing store, blacksmith, arcane and potion shop, as well as an enchantment store for magic weapons and items."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"In their free time, elves often spent their time in the Sleeping Unicorn Inn."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Later on, around year 337, Elyse was conquered by Koshites, who destroyed a big part of the forest in the Battle of the Burned Trees."]]]]}

entries.title: Elysian Forest
entries.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[],"markups":[],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"A medium sized forest, one of the many arcane wilds that have tremendous magical energies around it and where the space within the forest the magical energy is almost limitless."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Each arcane forest is a sacred ground for the goddesses and primordials which dwell within its boundaries. This particular arcane wild is one of the few groves touched with an Eternal Blessing from Lady of Forests, the sacred goddess of vitality, love, and nature. Many from Mirfield are cautious to go near the forest, claiming it to be fraught with danger. Rumors and tales speak of treants, unicorns, manticores, and other arcane creatures protecting the forest until an Arcane Guard awakens from a Soul Seed to speak with the primordials of the wilds, and stop a plot to rekindle the primordial wars with the gods."]]]]}

entries.title: Silvermount
entries.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[],"markups":[],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Dwarven town which makes its income by mining the Silver Mountain’s foothills. It is highly industrialized - most of the dwarves here work with stone, metals and gems. As in typical dwarven society, xenophobia is a common phenomenon. Any race other than dwarf, gnome, halfling or human can feel discriminated here. They especially hate sharp-eared races, like orcs or elves. Many of Silvermount dwarves believe in Murn guidance."]]]]}

entries.title: Temple of Sacred Oil
entries.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[],"markups":[["a",["href","https://docs.google.com/document/d/1v-Vwp3njTB_xQVpuhw9d3rRaW1tbIlSU17E5Yy_zZY0/edit#heading=h.sxteu3m72i1w"]]],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The Temple of Sacred Oil is a massive city wide cathedral for the Church of the Phoenix (see"],[0,[0],1," "],[0,[],0,"Kousher). The temple gets its name from the massive lake of oil inside, whether that lake was a natural gift from their god, or is imported, only the higher ups know. River named Acsena flows on western border of temple's region."]]]]}

entries.title: Face Fields
entries.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[],"markups":[],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The Face Fields were a set of fields in which lay the faces of gods and titans, places of constant change and melancholy by their nature. It is said by some to be the work of the battles that previously took place within them that it is a place of constant chaos and uncontrolled change. It is unknown where their holes, which were formed during the battles between titans, lead. Most scholars agree that face fields are a place of constant change, and chaos- It is said that it acts as a gateway between different realms, as it’s ever shifting surface leaves only the most skilled of pathfinders to know where exactly they are trying to go. It is speculated that the faces themselves are in fact holes, and portals between different planes of existence. It is a world outside of space time, and plagued by constant sand storms and otherworldly beasts that have been driven mad by years of constant wars with little else to do, but fight. And through it all, they still smile."]]]]}

entries.title: Cave of Boll
entries.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[],"markups":[],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"A cave which leads to the underworld, wherein demons roam and the souls of those that associated with them lay in torment. It is said that some view the gods with pure hate, and view humans as mere tools for their disposal- To such ends they will force many into servitude after death, putting them into the bodies of feral tieflings and forcing them to live and die, over and over until their minds rot out of their skull, only to be replaced by another as the cycle begins anew. Afterwhich their spirit is unceremoniously devoured by hordes of rabid beasts. Not all tieflings are like this, but those that are provide enough reason in and of themselves to be cautious."]]]]}

entries.title: Scorched Fields
entries.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[],"markups":[],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Hunting grounds of a huge dragon. The ancient black dragon Eioglmir continuously mourns the two children of hers, whom she once found turned to stone, alongside her other missing (rumours say adoptive) child, who she has not seen since her other children died. The area is inhabited by gnomes and halflings, which hide from dragon in dirt mounds."]]]]}

entries.title: Town on Fire
entries.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[],"markups":[],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Town periodically burned down by aggressive black dragon called Ejoglmir, which hunting grounds are few miles to the east, as well as multiple red-cloaked wizards. It was said to be an orc village once. Now it serves as a hideout for various Underworld outcasts coming from The Cave of Boll."]]]]}

entries.title: Lake of Alestria
entries.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[],"markups":[],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Huge lake in the middle of the Elysian Forest. It is occupied by multiple amphibian and reptile tribes, like bullywugs, lizardmen, tortles, and some dragonborn individuals."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Before year 837 the lake was split into three smaller lakes."]]]]}

entries.title: Silver Mountain
entries.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[],"markups":[],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The highest peak in the whole of Ashenland. It is said to be an extinguished volcano. It erupted around year 337, when avatar of Kousher woke up from its slumber."]]]]}

entries.title: Agmeth
entries.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[],"markups":[],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"A huge underground city situated in Plane of Greed. It was built for local fiends and their servants. The city consists of network of carved tunnels with spacious halls at some of the intersections. In its center, there's a cave with a giant throne called Throne of Greed. It's a place where the plane's ruler, Balros, resides."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The place was designed and built by the dwarves, hungry for treasures possessed by Balros, Lord of Greed. After years of hard work, Balros offered them what they wanted as a payment for their effort. The treasure was in fact cursed, making the dwarves craving for wealth even more. Many of them decided to stay in demonic dimension forever, fulfilling the town's need for a lower caste of workers."]]],[1,"h2",[[0,[],0,"Districts"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The town is split into number of districts, each focused around at least one of the greatest halls."]]],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"District of Demons"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The main district of the town, serving recreational and business purposes. Consists of inn, prison, treasury and banquet room. There's a big, burning goblet standing in water pool in the main hall. Inhabited mostly by - as name points to - demons and other fiends. Gambling and shady deals are a common phenomenon. It's guarded by squad of goat-people and minotaurs. It is said that some of them are in reality insubordinate dwarves transformed into half-beasts by Balros himself. It's also a place where administration of Exet, the local financial corporation, often meets up to plan its next steps and issue orders to its executives."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"In year 237 the district was defended from siege of forces lead by Galhor, demon of Wrath. The leader of attacking army was killed."]]],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"District of Dwarves"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"District full of dwarves and other non-fiends who decided to stay in (or were unable to leave) Agmeth. Before year 237, district was ruled by Peter, one of four head members of Exet corporation. He was killed by group of adventurers when an immigration crysis arose, leading to district being flushed with refugees from Fyren, an underworld town held in terror by nation of Wrath. Since then, the district unofficially regained its independence (there's still many fiends who think of dwarves as slaves)."]]],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"Throne of Greed"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Not a literal district, but rather a district-sized cave full of shiny treasure mounds with a giant throne made of skulls in the middle of it. It's full of golden statues, which were once Balros' enemies. The place is full of floating, burning skulls playing the roles of torches."]]]]}

entries.title: Edenberg
entries.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[],"markups":[],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Edenberg was founded 1225 near a marble quarry and marble tile factory owned by now deceased Adolf Benedict Einwald. It's population consists of humans, mostly former workers with their children and grandchildren. Unfortunately, after the rather unfortunate incident at the factory in 1280, it was closed. Youth flocked out of town, and with each passing year it's less and less populated."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Edenberg consists of two main streets, meeting at a crossroads in the dead center of this settlement, near the main convenience store, public transport stop and governmental utility building. Einwald manor, surrounded with a lush fields, is located almost directly to the north at the end of Main Road, while hospital, factory and quarry are located to the south at the other end. Another street goes approximately from NNW to SSE. There are a multitude of small streets connecting these two, including Forest Road, that is farthest to the north and is often used to get out of the town from the manor directly, thus well maintained in the past and abandoned now."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"There is no distinct culture to this short-lived town, except for a set of slightly odd urban legends."]]],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"The Incident"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"In year 1280, miners struck a weird cave-like formation while expanding the quarry. They say that there was a cave-in and somebody got hurt, although nobody can remember, who exactly it was. Shortly after that factory was closed for good, workers fired and equipment salvaged and sold in bulk as metal scraps. Some time after that elderly A. B. Einwald died, as rumors say, from stress-induced heart attack. It was shortly after his 100th birthday, so one could say he lived a long and fulfilling life."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"As weird as it is, any official investigations commenced didn't yield a tangible result."]]]]}

entries.title: Tonnis
entries.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[],"markups":[],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Capital of the Taruran Empire. Formerly Human hamlet, conquered by Goblins in year 337 after Great Event. Goblins, in act of reconciliation, named the town after Tonnis, the Human paladin."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The town was once a place of Kobold intrigue, during which a group of adventurers managed to prevent a young red dragon and his cult from taking over the town. In later times, the town was a place of many battles against Alisonian Empire's forces."]]],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"History"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Goblins and their relatives have a very bad relationship with the majority of other races. Although some of these are based upon old tradition without much actual proof to back it up (in case of Dwarves or Elves) some do have reason for distrusting goblins."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Long ago, before the Great Event, Humans and Goblins attempted to live in peace through an experimental, inter-species county located on the desert. This was quickly disbanded as the cultures collided, leading to riots and constant fighting. The reason to it was that Humans and other races had treated Goblins so poorly for thousands of years that they had grown to distrust Humans, leading to display of discrimination, racism and xenophobia. This lead to a Goblin takeover of the county after having been oppressed. The Goblins took over the town but were quickly dispatched by Human soldiers lead by general Tonnis. Both species used this as a way to affirm their own superiority and neither race has tried something remotely similar until year 337 after Great Event, when goblin Warlord Dober took over the county once more for goblinkind. He turned it into a county of all races, similar to the experiment, but with an already established hierarchy, which let the town prosper. As the first act of respect to their former enemies, Dober ordered to name the town after the Human general."]]],[1,"blockquote",[[0,[],0,"\"The other races and factions have been fighting each other. We have taken this city, not only as a show of our strength, but of their weakness! They have weapons of silver and destruction that they use, not for gain for their own people, but the detriment of ours, and so many like us, and yet we are the uncivilized ones. We fight tooth and nail to survive whilst they kill each other for entertainment, and yet we are the uncivilized ones, they grow corrupt and use this so called \"civilization\" for personal gain, and yet we are the uncivilized ones. These people destroy homes and families, and yet WE are the monsters! We are the monsters NO MORE! The time for mindless hiding is over! Shall the petty beings, who think themselves superior because of their own lack of understanding, morals and strength, physically and mentally, fall before our blades! WE TOGETHER SHALL RIDE INTO A NEW AGE!\" - Warlord Dober, Tonnisian Adress"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"During the revolution, a military group called Taruraj emerged from Dober's followers."]]]]}

entries.title: Shatterstone
entries.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[],"markups":[],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"A village not far from Ketu. "]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Shatterstone, or meta village, is a quite strange place both because of its people and the place it's been set. Village is set in a crater, between two gargantuan boulders that seem to two halves of a colossal meteorite. There is one big hole on the each part of the giant meteorite and if your imagination is strong enough you can easily say that when this thing fell something break out of it. However the strange things happening around the meteor don't end here. Area around it maintains a stable body temperature regardless of the extreme desert conditions."]]],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"Meta humans"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The village is a living space for special human race called meta humans. The place in year 387 was inhabited by circa thousand people who make their life by trade and farming since the weather is unnaturally convenient around the rock. They believe in Farseer, an enigmatic being which is said to commune with them in their dreams."]]]]}

entries.title: Ethereal Plane
entries.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[],"markups":[],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"More commonly called a Spiritual Plane or Plane of Souls, it's a plane of existence free of bodily constraints, where the mortal soul appears directly upon leaving its host - before continuing to its final destination. It partially overlaps with the material plane - allowing for seamless, although distorted glimpses of various places, people and ongoing events in the Physical Plane."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Its black sky is full of pale, colourful lights forming fanciful nebulae, each light representing a single lost soul waiting for redemption. Some of them descend to follow the imagery of their former world, hoping to find a way back to the living - seen by the mortals as apparitions, ghosts, phantoms, spectres and wraiths."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The purest souls can rise higher than any other soul, to become more visible for favourable gods whose servants and avatars visit the plane from time to time. Those souls who have committed great sins are bound to hover closer to the ground, making an easy prey to evil creatures like demons - some of them specialized in devouring stray souls of the Ethereal Plane."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Souls can take various sizes, shapes and colours - with the most common being a small, pale, cyan point light. The maximum size both their visual representation and their aura can take is limited by their power, which comes from absorbing it from other souls (usually weaker). The shape suggests the level of soul's transcendence - with the most aware souls capable of taking unreal forms, or even shifting their shape at will. Colour of a soul's aura points to its so-called aspect - the path of fate it is supposed to follow. The good souls tend to have brighter aura, while the evil souls have darker. Sometimes their colour may change accordingly to the choices they make."]]]]}

entries.title: Ashenland
entries.mobiledoc:
