The Combat"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Maintaining order in casual roleplay is fairly simple, when comparing it to combat procedures. That's why turn order in combat is a must-have. Unless some rules state otherwise, your character has four types of actions you can perform each turn: Movement, Action, Bonus Action and Reaction. You can imagine combat turn being a 6-second moment."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"You can find a nice cheat sheet for combat actions in D&D 5e "],[0,[7],1,"here"],[0,[],0,"."]]],[1,"h4",[[0,[0],1,"3.1 Move"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"You can move at any time during your turn (before, after, or during actions). It consumes your movement points, equal to your character's Speed."]]],[1,"h4",[[0,[0],1,"3.2. Action"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"You can also interact with one object or feature of the environment in a meaningful way, like attacking, casting a spell on some target, pulling a rope..."]]],[1,"h4",[[0,[0,0,0],2,"3.3"],[0,[],0," "],[0,[0,0],3,"Bonus Action"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"You can take a bonus action only when a special ability, spell, or feature which states that you can do something as a bonus action."]]],[1,"h4",[[0,[0],1,"3.4 Reaction"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"A reaction is an instant response to a trigger of some kind, which can occur on your turn or on someone else's."]]],[1,"h4",[[0,[0],1,"3.5 Free Action"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Your Turn can include a variety of flourishes that require neither your action nor your move, like talking, dropping an item, opening door, toppling some light object, stopping concentration on spell, dropping prone. Interacting with multiple objects during such Free Action may evolve into spending normal Action on it."]]],[1,"h4",[[0,[0],1,"3.6 Efficient Combat"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"In order to keep the turns shorter than one minute (and to avoid communicative ping-pong), players are advised to think and prepare aggregated action descriptions between turns, and send them (using "],[0,[0],1,"/e"],[0,[],0,") at the beginning of their own turns - along showing appropriate description cards and dice rolls, e.g.:"]]],[1,"blockquote",[[0,[5,0],2,"Ophiuchus uses Quickened Spell to cast Fire Bolt (as Bonus Action) on closest Ratman. Then, he jumps behind the rock. Afterwards, he casts another Fire Bolt (as Action) on the Ratman Archer in the distance (or on the first Ratman, if he survived). If the archer survives, Ophiuchus goes prone to get full cover."]]],[1,"blockquote",[[0,[0],1,"Quickened Spell"],[1,[],0,15],[0,[],0,"When you Cast a Spell that has a Casting Time of 1 action, "],[1,[],0,16],[0,[],0,"you can spend 2 sorcery points to change the Casting Time "],[1,[],0,17],[0,[],0,"to 1 Bonus Action for this casting."]]],[1,"blockquote",[[0,[0],1,"7 | 13"],[1,[],0,18],[0,[],0,"120 ft"],[1,[],0,19],[0,[0],1,"Fire Bolt"],[0,[],0," (+3)"],[1,[],0,20],[0,[0],1,"9"],[0,[],0," (Fire)"]]],[1,"blockquote",[[0,[0],1,"16 | 5"],[1,[],0,21],[0,[],0,"120 ft"],[1,[],0,22],[0,[0],1,"Fire Bolt"],[0,[],0," (+3)"],[1,[],0,23],[0,[0],1,"7"],[0,[],0," (Fire)"]]],[1,"blockquote",[[0,[5,0],1,"*Fir"],[0,[5,5,5,0,5],2,"st bolt misses the closest goblin, but the second one scorches "],[1,[],0,24],[0,[0,5],3,"him to death"],[0,[0,5],4,"!"],[0,[0],2,"*"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"(Last block was DM's response)"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The only valid excuses to making your turn longer are:"]]],[3,"ul",[[[0,[],0,"Action you want to perform has some very specific condition (requiring to) which can be resolved only after DM's output"]],[[0,[],0,"Action you want to perform can't be clarified by first page of Google results or asking other players"]]]],[1,"h3",[[0,[0],1,"4. The Aftermath"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Everything has its end, even RPG sessions. The campaign however, doesn't end that fast. There's a bunch of things that may happen after a session."]]],[1,"h4",[[0,[0,0,0],3,"4.1 Experience"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"From time to time, when adventurers achieved something significant (so-called milestone leveling), DM may reward all of them with one level. Characters get also levels for each personal sidequest which was completed on the session, so make sure to remind your DM that your character deserves some progression."]]],[1,"h4",[[0,[0,0,0],2,"4.2 Inspiration Vot"],[0,[],1,"e"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Players can vote for the subjectively best roleplayer using "],[0,[0],1,"#inspiration"],[0,[],0," macro. Whether through playing by character, or by some funny moment, winner gets Inspiration point. If the winner already has the Inspiration, point goes to another, highest voted person, and so on. If every Player Character has Inspiration at the end of a given session, Inspiration goes to NPC of choice."]]],[1,"h4",[[0,[0],1,"4.3 Discord roleplay"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Optionally, you can continue roleplaying on adequate Discord channel. It's also possible to roll dice there, but try to limit it since DM isn't always present between the games. If you do so, please mention him with "],[0,[0],1,"@"],[0,[],0," mark. Otherwise, don't be surprised events on session don't include your actions you posted on Discord."]]]]}

Player name can be replaced with \"gm\", to whisper the Narrator."],[1,[],0,0]]],[1,"blockquote",[[0,[0],1,"(To Aleks K.)"],[0,[],0," What was on previous session?"]]],[1,"blockquote",[[0,[0],1,"(From Aleks K.)"],[0,[],0," Goblin killing. And we found that artifact."]]],[1,"blockquote",[[0,[0],1,"(To Narrator)"],[0,[],0," I would like to escape silently, without other "],[1,[],0,1],[0,[],0,"characters knowing."]]],[1,"blockquote",[[0,[0],1,"(From Narrator)"],[0,[],0," Whisper -1 roll to me, because they outnumber you."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Narrator prioritizes responding to public messages over whispering, so before you decide to whisper him, ask yourself if it really should remain a secret. If not, perhaps you can simply engage other players and their characters into it?"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Try to avoid roleplaying with other players in private, but if such thing happens - inform Narrator about potential story changes to avoid unnecessary branching."]]],[1,"h4",[[0,[0],1,"2.4 Acting"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"All non-spoken actions should be performed with "],[0,[0],1,"/e <description>"],[0,[],0," command, e.g.:"]]],[1,"blockquote",[[0,[3,0],2,"Liszt plays a calming song on her viol"]]],[1,"blockquote",[[0,[3,0],2,"Crescent Moon tries to throw his glaive at the nasty "],[1,[],0,2],[0,[3,0],2,"monster"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"If your character moved during the action, drag your character's token to appropriate place on map."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"If other player characters aren't supposed to know what you're attempting to do (because they're all too far away or you want to be stealthy), consider whispering to Narrator description of your actions."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"In case the action's outcome is questionable or the action itself was non-trivial, Narrator can ask you to roll for it (see 2.5)."]]],[1,"h4",[[0,[0],1,"2.5 Rolling"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Sometimes your roleplayed action will cause a significant effect in the story. ("],[0,[],0,"Narrator"],[0,[0],2,"):"],[0,[],0," (how do you know? let's flip a coin, to see if this one doesn't regenerate after being hit with fire...)"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Sometimes Narrator is obligated to counter meta-gaming - just like in the last example."]]],[1,"h3",[[0,[0],1,"3. The Aftermath"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Everything has its end, even RPG sessions. The campaign however, doesn't end that fast. There's a bunch of things that may happen after a session."]]],[1,"h4",[[0,[0],0,"3"],[0,[0,0],2,".1 "],[0,[],1,"Level Up"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Characters get levels for completing their personal goal on the session, so make sure to remind your Narrator that your character deserves some progression."]]],[1,"h4",[[0,[0],1,"3.2 Discord roleplay"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Optionally, you can continue roleplaying on adequate Discord channel. It's also possible to roll dice there, but try to limit it to one roll between the sessions since Narrator isn't always present between the games. If you do so, please mention him with "],[0,[0],1,"@"],[0,[],0," symbol or inform him privately. Otherwise, don't be surprised events on session don't include your actions you posted on Discord."]]]]}

entries.title: Game Master's Guide
entries.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}],["soft-return","",{}]],"cards":[["image",{"src":"https://pbs.twimg.com/media/DySPBBpVAAI1LGl.jpg","alt":"","title":"","caption":"Not like you can't pick all three of them, but you'll soon pay for it with your sanity and burn-out syndrome","cardWidth":""}]],"markups":[["strong"]],"sections":[[1,"h2",[[0,[],0,"Dictionary"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"We're going to use a bunch of nerdy abbreviations:"]]],[3,"ul",[[[0,[],0,"DM - Dungeon Master, see GM"]],[[0,[],0,"dX - X-sided die"]],[[0,[],0,"GM - Game Master (you)"]],[[0,[],0,"NPC - Non-Player Character, a side character you're going to use to interact with the players"]],[[0,[],0,"PC - Player Character, the character created and played by a player other than you"]],[[0,[],0,"TPK - Total Party Kill, when GM allows all PCs to die (usually a bad move)"]],[[0,[],0,"ttRPG - Tabletop Roleplaying Game, a type of game you're going to play"]]]],[1,"h2",[[0,[],0,"Introduction"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"A Game Master is a special type of a player in tabletop roleplaying games. He's a master of ceremony, whose judgement should be acknowledged with respect. But with great power, comes great responsibility - if you don't want your players to quit after (or worse - during) the first session of your campaign, you need to prepare an acceptable course of events for whatever they decide to do. Overall, you're the person who makes sure everyone is having fun, more than anyone else."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"If you need a reference to more familiar concepts, you can think of a Game Master like of some kind of animator, storyteller, actor, improviser, stand-upper, but also a cartographer, scenographer, deejay, author, writer, lector, poet, singer, director, designer, mediator, arbiter, referee, jury, manager and a babysitter. The rest of the players are expected to be primarily just the actors (those lucky bastards!). But don't forget - anything more they can do means less work for you."]]],[1,"h2",[[0,[],0,"Gamemastering 101"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Let's start from listing your seven primary roles. I'm not sure if there really has to be seven of them, but seven is considered a lucky number - and boy, you'll need a lot of luck!"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[0],1,"1. Knowing your game's world"],[0,[],0,". You can create it yourself (aka 'worldbuilding'), or borrow it from existing work of art. Many ttRPG books contain unique, game-ready settings to choose from. Whichever option you choose, make sure you have a grasp on where the PCs are and what types of events are appropriate for describing to players. For example, featuring unicorn in a spaceship can potentially break immersion."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"It's good to consult the setting with the other players - perhaps some of them prefer horrors, while the others are fans of cute animals. Post some survey among them and let them pick the best-suiting theme. Of course, your vote counts more than anyone else's, but don't overuse this privilege or you'll be perceived as some stubborn dictator."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[0],1,"2. Knowing your game's system."],[0,[],0," Game system is the key feature of ttRPGs which make them different from a mere 'make believe' game. The system contains set of rules which provides unified data model for all PCs and aids GM in resolving outcomes of various events. Rule books often contain sample content to choose from, compatible with its system."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The systems are - more often than not - tailored under specific settings - for example, some of them include pages of gunfight rules, with detailed ammunition usage and various predefined body parts to hit. Works nice for western-themed games, but won't be that useful for high fantasy with swords and spells. Same as with picking a setting, try to pick the system together with the players."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[0],1,"3. Planning story for upcoming session(s)."],[0,[],0," It's an evolving structure of - often sequential - events that already happened, will happen, or sometimes won't happen in your campaign. You need to have at least a few key points planned, which you will be trying to achieve on next session - when the time is right. Let's call it a 'story'."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The first thing to start with would be to read PC's sheets. They usually include some biography and/or motivation of selected character. Try to jump into their shoes for a moment, and deduce what each of them wants to achieve. Feel free to consult the players about it."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"You can make so-called \"Session Zero\", where you'll help the players finish their characters' creation process and let them establish their goals. It's also the moment where they, as the players, share their expectations about the game. Try to find out the common factor which united their characters during the first session and describe the place they meet. While you're focusing on some PC's missing details, the others can practice their roleplaying skills."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Once everyone's ready, let every PC introduce him/herself to the rest of the party. At this point, the players should already have couple of ideas about the form of their characters' cooperation - pick a couple of good ones and incorporate them into the story you have been thinking about as a GM. Then, put everything into nice words and introduce them into the story ahead."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The story in next sessions will be now dependent mostly on what you have prepared for your players. The session scenario usually consists of some introduction with short recap of what happened on the previous one, the middle part where you try to reach the key events you have planned for the session, and the ending, which role is to finalize unfinished threads (if it's possible) and give the PCs some naturally-looking moment of rest - or, a proper ending - if it's the last session of the campaign."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[0],1,"4. Preparing the tools."],[0,[],0," By tools I mean all the things which enable or enhance a roleplaying game session. Their role is to organize known details, help visualising the current situation during the session,  and increase the overall immersion in the game world."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The most obvious items you will need are the character sheets. Players often prepare them by themselves, but you'll still have to review them and use during sessions to double-check some important character info. You can also bring your GM notes with you - just in case you forget about some ideas you have listed before. Many systems provide cheat-sheets with the most important rules you can use - but make sure to have the complete rulebook somewhere nearby as well."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The next step would be to prepare something you can write/draw on, be it simply a piece of paper + pencil, dry-erase whiteboard + markers or some graphics software. It's important to have some option of modifying your work, so make sure to bring a rubber or whiteboard eraser, respectively. If you plan to secretively distribute info among various players during the game, then sticky notes will surely help in it (if you are a tree lover then choose some messaging app for that extra channel of privacy)."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Now, the handouts. These are printed or manually written sheets of paper you prepare before the session. They include various pieces of information relevant to the story - like a map, a letter, a photo or a drawing. Do you plan to recite some lengthy, dramatic quote to your players? Make it a handout instead - burn its sides and spray with droplets of strawberry juice - and let the PCs find it somewhere."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Time for the gadgets - the items which generally don't provide any complex information by themselves, but can be used to make the game more interactive (and some systems require them). They include many-sided dice, cards, coins, tokens, figurines, musical instruments and any other artifacts you can think of."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Finally, the digital media. Even if you don't play online, you can still consider using modern inventions like recorded music and videos. A proper soundtrack playing in the background of your session is a definitive boost to the overall immersion."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[0],1,"5. Scheduling sessions."],[0,[],0," When, where and who will you meet with. Feel free to outsource this task to your players, but be aware you're the person who benefits the most from knowing if some player will be present or absent on upcoming session (since it can affect the events which you plan to present)."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"It's good to keep an eye on players' free times, for example by using some scheduling software. Players enter their free times into a nice poll, which outputs the best time slots for the session. Alternatively, you can say you're a busy GM and there is only one specific hour you can run the session - but don't be surprised if you'll have to cancel the session due to insufficient players."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The place of the session is an important factor. Optimally, you'll want to have a logistically viable, cozy space with as few disruptions as possible. If you're not playing online, it should also feature some flat surface with option to sit around."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Last but not least, players themselves. On average, a GM plays more sessions with people who live in the same place (or - in a similar timezone, if you're playing online). The age of the players is also worth noting, since you shouldn't feature heavy drinks among underages, nor describe NSFW details to them. Be aware of inviting your other half - you should treat everyone equally (regardless if you're GM or a normal player), and if you're too used to displaying your feelings, the other players may start boycotting you."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[0],1,"6. Implementing the story into the session's plot."],[0,[],0," The moment your campaign starts, you need to present the story (aka 'storytelling') to the players in more or less direct way - using various media like voice, text, images, videos or sounds, often improvising some scenic details on the run. Let's call the final result of it a 'plot'."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The players certainly won't follow the exact plan you had in mind before the session - the sad truth is that there is only a subset of all possible events which you have prepared for. What if instead of left or right they go straight forward, through the wall? What if they start fighting each other? What if they don't do anything at all? It's a matter of time when you will be in a need to improvise and adapt."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Don't stick to particular sequence of events, a complete reorder doesn't sound half as bad as you think it sounds. If you'll start insisting on using the obvious options you've suggested, the players will quickly feel limited in the game's world, as the game itself will start looking like a predictable movie. Such situation is called 'railroad'."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"A story told with a pinch of roleplay and improvisation of all the players (including GM) becomes the campaign's plot - a summarized transcript of what happened so far. If you have decided to build your own lore (or write a book), you may consider spending some time between the sessions for picking the most memorable pieces and making them canonical events of your world."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[0],1,"7. Providing interaction with game world."],[0,[],0," Apart from following your planned story, you have to listen to what players say and provide a reasonable description on how does the environment respond to what PCs do. It means describing events, places, objects, but also NPCs' reactions - which you will have to roleplay by yourself (similarly to how players roleplay their PCs)."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Try to stay tuned with what do your players want to achieve, and synchronize with them, making their PCs' actions significant and memorable. Unless the immediate story includes obvious limitations in a given scene, provide the PCs with all kinds of services your world has to offer, adjusted to the circumstances they're in."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"When roleplaying NPCs, keep in mind their attitude to characters and a given situation. They do have, much like the PCs do, friends, enemies, families, homes and jobs which bias their way of thinking. Don't overshadow the PCs with fully-fleshed NPCs, though - to avoid stealing spotlight. Unless they're recurring characters, most of your NPCs should stay one-dimensional, with linear backstories or repulsive flaws - so that they won't distract players from the real story you have planned."]]],[1,"h2",[[0,[],0,"The Iron Triangle of GM-ing"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"You're assigned a really tedious task - before you put any effort in it, try to set up your mind on mostly two out of three main aspects of your preparation:"]]],[10,0],[1,"p",[[1,[],0,0],[0,[0],1,"Expensive approach"],[1,[],0,1],[0,[],0,"You buy the original rulebooks, story modules, software licences, tools, perhaps rent a room and order some food. It's in the best manner to split the costs among all players equally. As a GM, you don't really need to pay for all these stuff, especially if you're playing with complete strangers - in which case, you can even set your regular wage per session. Perhaps you could make some exception for a group of friends or relatives you like. This approach should save you a lot of time and improve the quality of game's experience for everyone."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[0],1,"Time-consuming approach"],[1,[],0,2],[0,[],0,"In this setup, I assume you're willing to spend much of your time to prepare, be it creating handouts, discussing details with the players, searching the internet for nice-looking maps, writing story, NPCs or designing the whole game world. It also means you're allowed to delay your sessions or run them more sporadically, if needed. Your players should arm themselves with heavenly patience. To make the process quicker, you can delegate your players to specific tasks."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[0],1,"Low quality approach"],[1,[],0,3],[0,[],0,"This is an option for people lacking commitment. Perhaps your group nominated you to be their GM because there was simply no better pick around? Or maybe you just want to run an one-shot session to prove yourself? Or maybe the game is just a pretext to meet with your friends? It's not designed to be good, but at least you'll understand the GM's perspective. The only salvation lies in your players - make sure they're experienced enough, so that they will be able to carry the story by themselves and help in filling gaps."]]],[1,"h2",[[0,[],0,"Dirty Hacks"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"The most of the game is about the way you present it to the players - there's no compulsion to tell them the exact temperature of air around their characters, the distance to nearest city, nor the colour of some character's hair. There will always be something left unsaid, what can be specified further. As simple as it sounds - you focus your thoughts on what your players focus theirs. People, places and objects pop out only when the camera points at them. The key is to create just the impression, nothing else."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"If any of your players has an ambition to judge you based on what he/she saw behind your scenes, you can politely tell him/her to get back to playing video games or training sport - if he prefers scripted or realistic approach, respectively. The game you're playing is neither of them. It's also the reason why you could want to hide the exact details on how do you achieve your effects - just like some of the GMs decide to use Game Master's screens to hide themselves from curious gazes and keep their dirty secrets unspoiled."],[1,[],0,4]]],[3,"ol",[[[0,[],0,"Keep the PCs in closed areas like dungeon to cut-off a whole range of uncomfortable traveling ideas they might come up with. It also helps in keeping the party together, what makes your narration easier"]],[[0,[],0,"Quickly learn to improvise on the run by tossing a coin whenever you've got doubt about some unexpected story detail which has to be defined - on heads you say 'Yes' and take the approach beneficial to the PCs, on tails you say 'No' and actively antagonize their dreams and hopes"]],[[0,[],0,"A rotated or mirrored map is basically a new map. Same thing applies to map assets and tokens. Use this knowledge if you're in urgent need of creating an impression of a vast, open world"]],[[0,[],0,"Let the players make the scenario for you! Tell them to write some decent character biographies including places and people they could have known and life-changing events they have experienced. Then just patch everything together into one common goal and launch them all in the most probable place they could have met in"]],[[0,[],0,"Let the players make the story for you! Keep track on players' suggestions, expectations, hopes and guesses (both in-character and out-of-character) during the game. If they don't collide with your story plan, make their wishes come true!"]],[[0,[],0,"Let the players make maps for you! If one of the characters is likely to know upcoming area, ask the player if he would like to find/create a map of it. Alternatively - make all players draw a map together in real time, while you're describing locations to them"]],[[0,[],0,"Keep your main scenario's points as flexible and general as possible, at the same time keeping loose lists of NPCs, places and items, which you can use to instantiate your grand plan accordingly to players' decisions. Did they kill an important NPC? Did they go in unexpected direction? Did they throw an ancient artifact away? Just pick another from the list, and go along your main scenario"]]]]]}
